Brilliant.

I was half debating going to my nonna's and making my own sausage. 2. The price of the lemon dessert. When you see it on the menu and you look at the price, it looks reasonable. Until they bring out the smallest friggen jar you've ever seen in your life. I'm surprised they even make spoons small enough to fit in there. I was expecting them to bring out a small child to scoop out the contents with their tiny fingers thats how small the jar was. Best lemon dessert I've ever had. Not sure it was worth college tuition.

title_review: Better pizza may exist, but this is a great place for quick, inexpensive and tasty eats!
review_preview: It's a short walk from the Gran Via metro station along the lively Calle Hortaleza. You can phone and your take-out will be waiting when you pick it up within minutes. We have walked up to the street window and not had a long wait...
review_full: It's a short walk from the Gran Via metro station along the lively Calle Hortaleza. You can phone and your take-out will be waiting when you pick it up within minutes. We have walked up to the street window and not had a long wait until the pizza was ready. Medium to smallish-sized pizzas cost 6 to 9 euros (truly a reasonable value). If you're watching you're figure you can probably share one or at least order just one, but most of us hogs require more than something to share. We have visited mid-week, sat at the counter, and had a great time watching the bustling staff prepare the pizzas and other food. Soon we found ourselves chatting with our pleasant and welcoming Brazilian waitress who was way cool. My spouse and I shared a mixed salad, a tasty pizza, a better than expected lasagna, and mostly we just inhaled our bottle of good chianti. You can't go wrong if it's a quick, inexpensive, fun-filled pizza place you're expecting (as opposed to a fine intimate dining experience)!!!

review_preview: From the outside this place looks like any other small pizza takeaway with a few seats inside but the pizzas are outstanding. We sat inside (it was busy and had to wait 5 minutes for a seat) and ordered what we wanted from an English...
review_full: From the outside this place looks like any other small pizza takeaway with a few seats inside but the pizzas are outstanding. We sat inside (it was busy and had to wait 5 minutes for a seat) and ordered what we wanted from an English menu. The pizzas are made in front of you with the freshest ingredients and come out of the oven piping hot, crispy and very tasty. This was a very cheap place to eat, particularly for Madrid. The quality of the food was outstanding and I would go as far as to say it was the best pizza I have ever had. The staff were also very friendly. The best value for money you'll find in Madrid!

review_preview: I must have passed this place around 30 times in my searches for a place to eat around my hotel and I didn't spare it too much attention because there's nothing great about the outside and I'm not a fan of places where they don't...
review_full: I must have passed this place around 30 times in my searches for a place to eat around my hotel and I didn't spare it too much attention because there's nothing great about the outside and I'm not a fan of places where they don't have actual tables. Then I read the reviews here and decided to give it a try and, boy, was I sorry not to have tried it earlier! It feels pretty intimate, when you stay at the bar and you see the staff behind it kneading dough and preparing your pizza. They're pretty friendly and greet you with a smile, they don't seem eager to throw you out because there is a crowd inside. The pizza was absolutely delicious both times I've tried it - not too puffy, not to slim and dry, well covered in topping. The pasta was also good, a real home-made feel to it. Another top point: the prices you see on the menu are the prices you will pay in the end. No taxes popping out of nowhere on the final bill. I hope they'll still be there next time I come to Madrid

title_review: Wonderful, cheap and cheerful, tasty fresh food.
review_preview: I used to live in this street and I had takeaway pizza and pasta from there all the time. Now it's all non-smoking, you can eat in there, if you can find a place at the bar! It's always packed because the food is wonderful....
review_full: I used to live in this street and I had takeaway pizza and pasta from there all the time. Now it's all non-smoking, you can eat in there, if you can find a place at the bar! It's always packed because the food is wonderful. The same 2 members of staff have been working there for at least 15 years. We had pasta with roquefort sauce and the aubergine stuffed with vegetables and two drinks for about 15 euros. I can't recommend this place enough. If you are in any of the nearby hostals or hotels in Chueca/Gran Via, this is a great option for a takeaway lunch/dinner.

title_review: A little slice if Italy in Madrid
review_preview: We LOVED this place!  We were staying just up the street at the Senator Gran Via and it was a simple little walk.  It's a hole in the wall place that you could walk right past if you aren't paying attention, but it's just down...
review_full: We LOVED this place! We were staying just up the street at the Senator Gran Via and it was a simple little walk. It's a hole in the wall place that you could walk right past if you aren't paying attention, but it's just down the Calle Hortaleza close to the Gran Via. They are only open in the evening, but it's worth the wait. We ordered a plain cheese pizza, a mushroom pizza, a chicken and artichoke pizza, and manicotti. Every single bite was DELICIOUS. The sauce is tangy and rich, the dough is crisp and decadent. We LOVED it! We had it our last night in Madrid, that is my only regret because I would have went back AGAIN and AGAIN.

title_review: Wonderful family run restaurant in Madrid
review_preview: Great Service, great food and a wonderful time. It was the last few nights we were on our family trip to Spain. We had been to Barcelona and all through the south, ending in Madrid. My in-laws had taken out entire family for their 50th...
review_full: Great Service, great food and a wonderful time. It was the last few nights we were on our family trip to Spain. We had been to Barcelona and all through the south, ending in Madrid. My in-laws had taken out entire family for their 50th wedding anniversary. This restaurant was the most wonderful experience. The owner was waiting for our group to come, the made us feel at home right away by seating us and bringing us tastings of food and drink. The attention to detail throughout the meal was wonderful. The brought our table great wine selections and deserts, it was truly special for our entire family. It was really a great place to go and eat even if it is just for 2, we were 10. title_review: If you seek "authentic" Spanish cuisine, start here
review_preview: Having read the earlier reviews here and elsewhere, and having double-checked our inclinations with a very helpful concierge, we trekked off to El Rincon de Esteban for our first of serious meal of recent holiday in Madrid. What a great choice. The restaurant is small,...
review_full: Having read the earlier reviews here and elsewhere, and having double-checked our inclinations with a very helpful concierge, we trekked off to El Rincon de Esteban for our first of serious meal of recent holiday in Madrid. What a great choice. The restaurant is small, intimate and feels as though you are seated in the owner's dining room (albeit one that appeared to accommodate about 12 or so tables). After explaining why we had chosen to eat here, the staff laid out a splendid spread of Spanish delicacies all savory, perfectly prepared and delicious. We sampled one fish and one lamb entree, numerous side dishes and at one bottle of house-recommended Rioja, which was tasty and went well with all of the food. As is the custom here, after we politely declined dessert lacking the capacity, the staff brought out with our coffee a large sample of candies, cookies and shots of Lemoncello. We spent less than $100 euro and could not top the experience over the next six days. Definitely worth trying, especially if authentic cuisine is the experience you desire.

title_review: warmest service i have ever received
review_preview: we visited this restaurant on sunday night when Casanis was closed. The nice hotel nearby recommended it when their restaurant was also closed. As we were walking in the waiter had stopped a couple who were at the door as the boss wanted to give...
review_full: we visited this restaurant on sunday night when Casanis was closed. The nice hotel nearby recommended it when their restaurant was also closed. As we were walking in the waiter had stopped a couple who were at the door as the boss wanted to give the lady a flower before leaving. it set the tone for the whole evening. A lovely older gentleman seated us in a little table in the corner. He was so warm it was like being served by family, he recommended the house red and used some english with us while we tried to use our spanish. He checked if we wanted the marinated anchovies laid out as a starter but we declined so they were removed and olives and the tastiest mini chorizos brought instead. He gave us a candle as he said we were young romantics and needed it more than the older group beside us. He also topped us both up, if ones glass ran lower than the other he still topped you both, adding a splash to the second. you wanted for nothing, yet not intrusive either. We had the chefs pate to start, very nice. Duck with Pomegranate jam and orange. Mains we had the steak with veg and fries. The meat was very good, mine was a little fatty but my husbands was not, it didnt matter though as i couldnt manage it all anyway. For pudding we had the creme catalan, a richer version of creme brule, fantastic, dont think of the calories just enjoy. Aftwards we had a small shot of a digestive liquor, it looks like lemoncelo but be warned its not it far stronger and our waiter thought it funny to top us up again.  Lastly he gave us a pen each as a gift, so lovely, the warmest service, really he saw us out to the door and wished us all the best. I would most definately return here on any trip to Madrid. It makes for a lovely quiet and relaxing romantic evening.

review_preview: Didn't know what to expect for our first night out in Madrid, but we were referred here by our hotel. (Oddly, when we returned to Madrid a week later, it was also recommended by our travel agent.) We were welcomed by the maitre'd and the...
review_full: Didn't know what to expect for our first night out in Madrid, but we were referred here by our hotel. (Oddly, when we returned to Madrid a week later, it was also recommended by our travel agent.) We were welcomed by the maitre'd and the wait staff made us feel right at home. The food was good, not spectacular, but the salad we ordered was a visual display of art and tasted excellent too. We felt attended to and in true Spanish tradition, never rushed. When you are looking for a place to wind down and enjoy a solid leisurely meal this is it. We would return without hesitation. The only caveat I would add for all Spanish restaurants and not just this one, is beware what is brought to you at your table that you may think is complimentary. Odds are, it isn't. Olives, bread, potatos bravatas, and an after dinner drink can all add to your bill. Other than that this is a stop well worth making. El Rincon brings dining back to the lexicon.

review_preview: For Madrile√±o diners, this well-known restaurant serving traditional dishes from a limited menu typical of the capital region is nothing new. Popular with politicians and lawyers from the nearby courts and parliamentary offices for decades, it's almost second nature: the place where nobody higher up...
review_full: For Madrile√±o diners, this well-known restaurant serving traditional dishes from a limited menu typical of the capital region is nothing new. Popular with politicians and lawyers from the nearby courts and parliamentary offices for decades, it's almost second nature: the place where nobody higher up the corporate food chain will question your decision. That does NOT negate its quality‚Äîwhen did you meet a well-paid lawyer who was prepared to eat second-rate cuisine? It's a restaurant based on tradition, albeit some murky too. Where quality and culinary heritage are the guiding principles, the issues of the clients are almost incidental. In my opinion, one where the heavier dishes of the winter months are actually the most impressive.

We were not charged extra for any of the dishes that appeared without having been ordered other than a cover charge for bread (which I did not object to). The meal ended with complimentary chocolates and a yellow liquor that can only be described as 'rocket fuel' but nonetheless delicious! Senor Esteban is charming as are all his staff and this is a wonderful restaurant if you want a romantic evening for 2. If you want lively tapas go further up the road into the Square of Santa Ana.

review_preview: Take it for what it is - and perhaps that includes some questionable salesmanship, but this quaint and out of the way restaurant manned by flirty oldsters was quite charming.  We were surrounded by locals, one a rather large group and the others smaller tables...
review_full: Take it for what it is - and perhaps that includes some questionable salesmanship, but this quaint and out of the way restaurant manned by flirty oldsters was quite charming. We were surrounded by locals, one a rather large group and the others smaller tables for two. While we did have several things delivered to our table that we did not order, we were only charged for a plate of large tasty olives and pickles. There was an amuse-bouche brought to the table before our meal and we had a glass of liquor poured after our meal that were not charged to us. This restaurant's recommendations came from several sources, our young hotel desk clerk told us she and their staff held its annual holiday party there. A couple of friends who are long-term Madrid residents recommended it as well. My dining companion and I both had fish dishes that were extraordinary in freshness and preparation. The hake was perfectly cooked. The large flakes of moist fish were mellow and delicately flavored. My friend had a sole prepared to her liking as well. As we left, the apparent owner came to bid us adieu with besos on both checks and a flower for each of us plucked from a nearby vase. Perhaps part of the salesmanship, but charming in any case.

review_preview: There are no words to describe this place, other than it is incredibly delicious!It was so nice to duck into this Taberna for a bite to eat. I read previous reviews on TripAdvisor and decided to stop by one early evening before the major...
review_full: There are no words to describe this place, other than it is incredibly delicious! It was so nice to duck into this Taberna for a bite to eat. I read previous reviews on TripAdvisor and decided to stop by one early evening before the major dinner rush around 7pm. The establishment appears small yet it is very deep. I was able to find a high-top table near the the door and others were either escorted to the bar or back room. Although small, many groups dined here and everyone appeared to have a great time.  Hungry, I ordered 3 tapas in Spanish then waited for about 10 minutes before my first plate arrived. Worth. The. Wait! After the first three I ordered two more. Here's what I ate: - croquetas de jam√≥n - Palitos de verdura (veggie sticks) - pollo crujiente (crispy chicken) - solomillo teriyaqui (teriyaki beef) - ceviche de langostinos y mango (prawn and mango ceviche) - two refresco limons I really stuffed myself and in hindsight I could've ordered less because the food was very hearty. The chef really focused on each individual tapa, pulling out the natural flavor of each of the ingredients all for a highly reasonable price. I felt like a queen feasting on a table full of delights. The vegetable sticks were a pleasant surprise. Upon arrival, I noticed they were lightly fried in batter and almost all of the dishes had some sort of "base", whether rice (beef teriyaki), potato chips (croquetas), a sweet or savory sauce, or salad. This was of no concern because everything blended well together.  If I ever have the opportunity to visit Madrid again you'd better believe I'm stopping here for a bite to eat!

review_preview: We stopped into Chato because of other reviews.The decor/lighting wasn't as cozy as I like, but the service and food did not disappoint.We enjoyed the pate, the crispy shrimp and several other tapas as well. The crispy chicken with cornfalkes disappointed, as it...
review_full: We stopped into Chato because of other reviews. The decor/lighting wasn't as cozy as I like, but the service and food did not disappoint. We enjoyed the pate, the crispy shrimp and several other tapas as well. The crispy chicken with cornfalkes disappointed, as it seemed to have been fried and refried as the coating was too dark, dried and cold. The croquetas, on the other hand, were probably the best I had in my 3 day visit to Madird and I tried a lot! The beer was good and my husband enjoyed his wine. The owner or manager seemed to take pride in his work and our waiter was very sweet. If you are in the area and looking for some snacks I'd give it a try. The portions are tiny but the prices were very reasonable. We didn't stay for too long but we enjoyed our visit.

Seating looks very limited - mostly around the bar or the window. We ordered croquettes, salmorejo, Caprese salad , pork iberican and brie cheese with dried tomatoes. Portions were generally small (starter size), but tasted good and looked good as well. Price was reasonable for the quality, but the big eaters may not be satisfied with the size of the tapas offered.

By accident we stumbled in to the El Rincon on our way home and discovered a classic old style Spanish restaurant. 19th century interior design with glass and mirrors, padded chairs and old men waiting the tables. title_review: While in Madrid, please don't miss it.
review_preview: El Rincon de Esteban is a restaurant located in Calle Santa Catalina in Madrid, real close to the Westin Palace. We visit Madrid quite often and we never leave without having dinner at this restaurant, where Esteban, the owner, welcomes you into it and makes...
review_full: El Rincon de Esteban is a restaurant located in Calle Santa Catalina in Madrid, real close to the Westin Palace. We visit Madrid quite often and we never leave without having dinner at this restaurant, where Esteban, the owner, welcomes you into it and makes you feel totally at home. Although the service is always excellent, the food is even better. No matter what Esteban has on the menu that day, I can assure you, you will be pleased. His famous "Manda Huevos Federico Trillo" is a plate that canhnot be eaten anywhere else in Spain and the Marmitako is to die for. I highly recommend you visit this fine restaurant that is sure to make you feel at home every time you go.

review_preview: We've just had a wonderful meal at Taberna del Chato, we were looking for modern interesting tapas and we found it. The food was great and very reasonably priced. Everything was beautifully presented and very tasty, plus the waiter was super friendly and cute ;)....
review_full: We've just had a wonderful meal at Taberna del Chato, we were looking for modern interesting tapas and we found it. The food was great and very reasonably priced. Everything was beautifully presented and very tasty, plus the waiter was super friendly and cute ;). We liked the pigeon pate, the crispy chicken served lollipop style, grilled octopus, mixed seafood salad and lots more. This time we went a la carte but they have a menu of tapas plus one racion and a bottle of wine for 15 euro per person which looks like a great deal, perhaps we'll go for that next time. They said they've been open seven months and I'm sure in a few more they'll be even better known. Highly recommended for excellent presentation, high quality ingredients and a warm friendly atmosphere, what more could you want? I'll be posting some pictures on my blog http://somuchmoretosee.blogspot.com.es/

Food was very good although my suckling pig was not up there to what I expected, but everybody else loved their food so I go with majority. The menu is traditional Spanish, and by that I mean from Spain proper. Location is excellent by The Palace, Urban and Villa Real hotels and by the Congress so you are in the center of Madrid. I love this area. Enjoy!

title_review: Christmas Dinner in Madrid--with Esteban and his Wife and their Friends
review_preview: This Dinner was PERFECT in every way.  Esteban and his Wife came to the dining room floor for photos with their patrons.  It felt as if we were part of the "family" as we enjoyed our Christmas dinners (one of us with red meat, the...
review_full: This Dinner was PERFECT in every way. Esteban and his Wife came to the dining room floor for photos with their patrons. It felt as if we were part of the "family" as we enjoyed our Christmas dinners (one of us with red meat, the other with fish). People talked to one another among the tables. Eel is very expensive, but a tradition in Madrid. Well, the eel (chopped up in) pil pil sauce on the hake (white fish) was a dream, and not overly expensive! A server refilled my glass, though I asked for no second glass, in order, I suspect, to make me feel as though I were part of the "party." We let the owner, Esteban Gonzalez have his way, and bring us his reommended dessert to share--apple pie unlike anything we have ever before tasted. (It's another Madrid Christmas tradition.) He rewarded us with mazapan, in wrappers, and other goodies, that we took back to our hotel for a snack during the next day's museum visits. We'll be back, Esteban!

title_review: EXPENSIVE!! Great food but beware of the additional costs they tack on to your bill.  Would not go back.
review_preview: So we walk in and they sit us down.  While we're figuring out what to eat, the waiter passes by and offers us a small plate of appetizers that he has in his hand.  Thinking it was on the house we accepted.  We then ordered,...
review_full: So we walk in and they sit us down. While we're figuring out what to eat, the waiter passes by and offers us a small plate of appetizers that he has in his hand. Thinking it was on the house we accepted. We then ordered, and our food was delicious. When we asked for the bill they tacked on a 12 euro cubiertos fee, and they charged us for what we thought was a complimentary appetizer. When we argued the additional costs the waiter didn't want to here it. In summary, the took advantage of the situation, and we left fairly upset. Although the food was great I would not recommend this restaurant as they're hundreds that are better and much less expensive. This lunch ended up being the most expensive meal on our trip, and we didn't even order a bottle of wine!!!

review_preview: We ate here for our last night in Madrid, and it was great. On the table when we arrived was a plate of what they called a "marriage" of 2 types of anchovies, fresh & salted. The waiter explained that for a starter we could...
review_full: We ate here for our last night in Madrid, and it was great. On the table when we arrived was a plate of what they called a "marriage" of 2 types of anchovies, fresh & salted. The waiter explained that for a starter we could have them accompanied by little toasts topped with fresh tomatoes, or we could choose a different starter. We chose the anchovies, and they were incredibly delicious. For our main courses, I ate suckling lamb chops and my husband had partridge Toledo-style (stew with onions and potatoes), both very good. We liked our dessert that was a cake with rum and whipped cream, kind of like a baba. Then they brought out a little plate of chocolate strips, citrus balls, etc., and then shots of a herbal-lemon liquer on the house. It was a very successful ending to our time in Madrid.

review_preview: Vesuvio is a very small place, so it really is hard to find a seat. And lots of people will be waiting behind your back to have your seat. The place is so small and crowded that it is almost impossible to take the attention...
review_full: Vesuvio is a very small place, so it really is hard to find a seat. And lots of people will be waiting behind your back to have your seat. The place is so small and crowded that it is almost impossible to take the attention of the staff. And unfortunately they do not speak English.  Despite being such a small place, pizza menu/list is simple but rich at the same time. Pizza is freshly made and you see how it is done. You can choose what to include and what not to include. Prices are affordable/low (around 6 euros if I am not wrong). I would recommend you to have additional cheese and basil (with additional prices) on your pizza to make it even more delicious. We have tried 3 different pizzas, 1 spagetti and salad which unexpectedly turned out to be pasta salad! I can suggest you not to try spagetti and pasta salad but I guess you will not regret any of the pizzas you will try. Enjoy good pizza with low prices at Vesuvio!

The beginning tapas was beyond excellent...especially an incredibly light square of some kind of egg dish like a frittata/souffle...so elegantly fragrant...melted in your mouth. I was a little disappointed with the main dish after all the fantastic beginning tapas and salad..i ordered a battered fish which ended up being a version of fish and chips and the chips were not especially great. I think I ordered wrong..the succulent lamb that was on another table looked like it might have been the way to go. All in all it was an excellent dining experience though and in a fantastic neighborhood that was delightful to walk around and shop and experience the locals.

title_review: exceptional spanish cuisine and welcoming staff
review_preview: we visited el rincon de esteban a number of times in october during our recent vacation in madrid.  we were delighted to find that the quality of the food has maintained the excellence that we found last year, and that the staff, beginning with the...
review_full: we visited el rincon de esteban a number of times in october during our recent vacation in madrid. we were delighted to find that the quality of the food has maintained the excellence that we found last year, and that the staff, beginning with the personable and charming Esteban are still there , welcoming their guests and encouraging them to try the spanish cuisine. it is a charming restaurant with a wide choice of entrees for many different tastes and preferences, all served with generous portions. when you eat at Esteban's you can be sure of getting a delicious meal, personal attention, and a chance to interact with the other guests that Esteban encourages as though you were eating in his home!!!!! we have never left there without speaking and sharing a toast with the diners on either side of us. it just makes the whole experience so much more fun, and a truly "spanish experience", as Spainards go out of their way to make you feel welcome, especially Esteban. He and his restaurant are CHARMING!!!!!

title_review: A great place to grab a bite to eat on the go.
review_preview: We stumbled across this place on our way to Fox in a Box, (just a few minutes' walk round the corner). It's conveniently just off Gran Via, near the Metro. We didn't have a lot of time to grab some food and this turned out...
review_full: We stumbled across this place on our way to Fox in a Box, (just a few minutes' walk round the corner). It's conveniently just off Gran Via, near the Metro. We didn't have a lot of time to grab some food and this turned out to be perfect. There's not much room - just grab a stool at the bar and enjoy the bustle. They have an English version of their menu so us tourists can understand what we're ordering! My ham, pineapple and salami pizza was made in front of me, (complete with dough spinning in the air), and was really delicious. The rest of my party had pizzas and a salad, all of which were prepared speedily and consumed the same way. I believe they serve beers though we were only on soft drinks. I also saw pizzas and pastas being prepared for takeaway.

title_review: Cheap, no frills, delicious pizza in Madrid
review_preview: We had a serious craving for pizza one day in Madrid and remembered passing Vesuvio one night and knew it was good judging by how full the restaurant was. The pizzas are cheap and simple (tomato, mozzarella & mushrooms or anchioves for ~5 euro) and...
review_full: We had a serious craving for pizza one day in Madrid and remembered passing Vesuvio one night and knew it was good judging by how full the restaurant was. The pizzas are cheap and simple (tomato, mozzarella & mushrooms or anchioves for ~5 euro) and were the perfect size for us. The bases were perfect - soft in the centre and the crust was perfectly crisp. The tomato base tasted fresh and well-balanced.  It was pretty busy while we were there and the interiors is pretty traditional and no frills. Yes, the menu is in Spanish but pretty easy to decipher and staff were direct but helpful. Loved it!

title_review: Great restaurant off the beaten path
review_preview: It was a hot day in Madrid and after our stop at Oriol Balaguer we wondered in the area. We were near Sorolla Museum in a very quiet street. We were tempted to go in for a quick pick, but decided it might take a...
review_full: It was a hot day in Madrid and after our stop at Oriol Balaguer we wondered in the area. We were near Sorolla Museum in a very quiet street. We were tempted to go in for a quick pick, but decided it might take a while to find a cab to take us to Lakasa. We waited a while and got lucky as the cab took us to the area near the restaurant. I noticed in Spain, the cabbies sometimes drop you off in the area that is close to your destination. We were the only non Spanish diners. There was one very nice staff member that spoke English and took care of us. I guess they don‚Äôt get that many tourists, because at the end he came over and thanked us for dining there. How refreshing is that? One big advantage about this restaurant was the fact that you could order many of their dishes in half portion. That way you can try a few things. Even the half portions were generous. we had: Coca de trigueros y setas con jugo de leche Green asparagus and mushroom tart with sheep‚Äôs milk juice We started with this very delicious and spring-y dish. The grassy asparagus was the perfect partner for the earthy delicious morel mushrooms. The egg added richness to this wonderful dish. When was the last time you were served morel mushrooms in a restaurant that didn‚Äôt cost an arm and a leg? Spanish are lucky. Garbanzos con carabinero Chickpea Stew with Red Shrimp As soon as I saw my beloved red shrimp listed on this dish, I was sold. I love chickpeas and this was such a comfort dish. The shrimp was cooked beautifully. Bacalao con crema de ajonegro con verduritas a la vainilla Cod confit with black garlic sauce and vegetables scented with vanilla This was an interesting dish. The cod was cooked medium rare and the vanilla and black garlic added sweetness to this dish. The veggies provided a little textural contrast to the dish. Presa de cerdo ib√©rico puro de bellota con verduras encurtidas y Comt√© Grilled Iberian pork, pickled veggies and Comt√© cheese The best was saved for last. The only problem with that was we were kind of full, but that didn‚Äôt stop us from enjoying this wonderful dish. The Iberian pork and Comt√© was umami marriage made in heaven. Fruta con yogurt After all that food we needed something light and healthy. The juicy, sweet fruit and the tart yogurt was a perfect ending. You can see the pictures at: https://travel4foodnart.wordpress.com/2015/06/19/restaurante-lakasa/

title_review: Thoughtful menu and very good value
review_preview: Lakasa is conveniently located, a ten minute walk or less from the Nuevos Ministerios transport center (although not in an area that draws lots of tourists). Once you arrive, you'll find tasteful, modern decor in a mid-sized venue (seats about 40). The menu is short,...
review_full: Lakasa is conveniently located, a ten minute walk or less from the Nuevos Ministerios transport center (although not in an area that draws lots of tourists). Once you arrive, you'll find tasteful, modern decor in a mid-sized venue (seats about 40). The menu is short, but well thought-out and has the option of small sized servings (media raciones). There are, of course, daily specials which are printed out. The wine list includes an excellent selection of Spanish and foreign wines, at very reasonable prices. Service is attentive and professional and, as noted in another review, the chef himself is the one who answers questions about the menu items, and takes orders. A knowledge of Spanish (at least menu items) is very helpful here, although our waiter was Italian and also spoke French and some English. We will definitely return.

review_preview: While you may not find the nicest or fanciest pizzas in town here, you‚Äôll definitely find some of the cheapest (cringe-worthy fast food stuff excluded). Given the really cheap prices, this place is always packed (and I mean literally always). Whether there‚Äôs rain or shine...
review_full: While you may not find the nicest or fanciest pizzas in town here, you‚Äôll definitely find some of the cheapest (cringe-worthy fast food stuff excluded). Given the really cheap prices, this place is always packed (and I mean literally always). Whether there‚Äôs rain or shine and whether it‚Äôs lunchtime or dinnertime by Spanish or international standards, finding a seat here is usually pretty hard (and I say seat because this place mostly functions as a bar and only has high stools for sitting down with no actual tables available). Additionally, they‚Äôre always taking orders for takeaway pizzas, which only complicates things more and makes the waiting time a bit long. Nevertheless, the pizzas are usually worth it, especially when you‚Äôre feeling particularly cold, hungry, or both, and are in serious need of some comfort food. Don‚Äôt expect anything grand, however, as the pizzas happen to be fairly small and also use really cheap ingredients, for not only is the cheese really average quality, but they use canned mushrooms instead of fresh ones. While I can understand their choice to use cheaper cheese, the canned mushrooms definitely seem to be a bit excessive to me since white mushrooms are usually readily available all-year round and don‚Äôt cost much at all. Overall, Vesuvio is about ‚Äúgetting the most bang for your buck‚Äù and having a quick, simple and cheap meal before running off to do something else.

review_preview: Dining at Lakasa was a phenomenal experience. The restaurant has the option to serve most of its dishes as half portions to have a more tapas like experience. This is what my wife and I elected to do. We started with the Idiazabal Cheese Fritters....
review_full: Dining at Lakasa was a phenomenal experience. The restaurant has the option to serve most of its dishes as half portions to have a more tapas like experience. This is what my wife and I elected to do. We started with the Idiazabal Cheese Fritters. These soft gooey balls exploded with warm cheesy goodness and were insanely addictive. Next we had the Deep Fried Shrimps with Lime Mayonese. These shrimps were lightly crisp and airy and paired nicely with the creamy lime mayonese. Next up was the Cured Cow Meat from Astorga with a Touch of Pepper. This rich and flavorful cured meat had a pleasant salty and smokiness. Next we had the Grilled Duck Foie with Sweet Truffle. The Foie was creamy and lightly toasted and topped with savory mushroom shavings. The Marinated Loin of Bonito with Tomato Sauce & Cherry Tomato was also amazing. The melt in your mouth fish was paired nicely with juicy tomatoes. The Roast Pork with Homemade Mole Sauce was next. The tender pork had a nicely crisp outside and topped with a flavorful and spicy mole sauce and crisp tortilla chips. Next we had a cheese selection featuring four cheeses and jams from different areas of Europe. The cheeses had a variety of enjoyable flavors and textures. Finally, we couldn‚Äôt decide what to order for dessert, so we ordered three. The first dessert was the Lemon Pie with Meringue & Crumble which was lemony tart, creamy and filled with crunchy graham pieces. The second was the Cr√®me Caramel made with Sheep‚Äôs Milk, which was a creamy sweet flan. Finally we had the Double Choco (Black & White). This dessert was chocolate bliss: creamy and rich with a nice sweetness and bitterness. Every dish we had was perfect! Overall, the food was exceptional and flavorful and Lakasa is a must visit when in Madrid.

title_review: Small cosy restaurant with great food and friendly staff
review_preview: Found this traditional Spanish cuisine restaurant on TripAdvisor and reserved through the site. It is a small cosy place with photos all over the walls showing the owner  with  many other guests. The staff was extremely friendly and professional. One waiter spoke perfect English as...
review_full: Found this traditional Spanish cuisine restaurant on TripAdvisor and reserved through the site. It is a small cosy place with photos all over the walls showing the owner with many other guests. The staff was extremely friendly and professional. One waiter spoke perfect English as he lived in NYC for 3 years. Our family of four ordered steak tenderloin, two servings of veal, and an egg dish with baby eels!! The owner was very attentive and checked in at our table several times throughout the dinner. We received a complementary sample of an interesting appetizer with pork and mashed potato, great bread and olive plate, and palate cleaners between courses. This was one of our most enjoyable dining experiences on our Madrid trip. Highly recommend this place.

review_preview: Having a Latin background, I've tried different tapas in a bunch of different restaurants and cities - but I must say the ones from Taberna del Chato are unique! Do not miss the croquetas de jam√≥n (ham), pollo al curry (chicken) and the solomillo teriyaqui...
review_full: Having a Latin background, I've tried different tapas in a bunch of different restaurants and cities - but I must say the ones from Taberna del Chato are unique! Do not miss the croquetas de jam√≥n (ham), pollo al curry (chicken) and the solomillo teriyaqui (of tender sirloin). Their menu is complemented by other side dishes, a la carte meals and desserts, if you're that hungry. The sangr√≠a is delicious and their list of cocktails is creative. The restaurant is located in the trendy and bohemian downtown Madrid, but still conserves its authenticity and should definitely not be considered a tourist trap. It is small and cosy enough, with a friendly and quick service. The bill for 2 people was 32 euros and we more than satisfied. I'll go there again soon! :D

review_full: Though it was recommended strongly by the concierge at the Westin Palace, Rincon de Estaban was a tired restaurant with mediocre food. What sets it apart, though, is the fact that it is a racket designed to rip you off. The two very kindly gentlemen ply you with extras that you think are free (and you accept to be polite), only to charge you for EVERYTHING when the bill comes. This included sardines we didn't want, a plate of cookies after dessert we didn't want (and didn't touch), after-dinner drinks that were virtually forced on us, etc. Even the bread on the table costs something like 9 euros. If you fall for the good reviews on this site and then have a similar experience, just circle the items on the bill that you didn't order, and ask the waiter to take them off.

title_review: Esteban's is a great stop in Madrid
review_preview: This restaurant was recommended by our concierge at our hotel.  Esteban is a charming man and made the whole experience wonderful. Our daughter is semi fluent in Spanish.  He conversed with her and did an excellent job of getting the order correct.  Our salads were...
review_full: This restaurant was recommended by our concierge at our hotel. Esteban is a charming man and made the whole experience wonderful. Our daughter is semi fluent in Spanish. He conversed with her and did an excellent job of getting the order correct. Our salads were excellent but relatively simple. He picked out a wine that was a Rioja. It was ok but not great and a bit overpriced at 45 euros. I had similar or better in Valencia for 15 Euro. My daughter and I had fish. It was well prepared and tasty. I had the sea bass Bibao and she had the Hake Bilbao. My wife had steamed vegetables that were adequate. We had the desert sampler which was quite amazing and topped it off with some arujo, a liquor from Spain. Price was a bit steep but again the experience was excellent.

title_review: What a find: More than Pizza and clearly a local hangout
review_preview: After a long day at the Prado, shopping and with little in the way of food we wandered out in search of something to eat.  Our plan for a 3 star Michelin was dashed but we wandered into this tiny hole in the wall.  We...
review_full: After a long day at the Prado, shopping and with little in the way of food we wandered out in search of something to eat. Our plan for a 3 star Michelin was dashed but we wandered into this tiny hole in the wall. We almost passed as hard to see if a place to sit but we found a stool. Good thing too because within about 20 minutes it was packed with locals. You can do take out but to stay in was awesome. The pizza as you might expect was incredible but the ravioli carbonara was to die for. Add a little house red and a salad and it was a meal that far exceeded any expectations.  The staff were incredibly nice, the people were almost all locals and very friendly. If the small space worries you they have take out (we took for breakfast) as well.  I would highly recommend and suspect you will be pleasantly surprised

The pizza is just a bit smaller than a North American medium, but quite adequate for the two of us. We cashed out at about 17‚Ç¨ including tip. Friendly, attentive servers and jovial atmosphere. Recommended.

title_review: An excellent dining experience in Madrid
review_preview: Our hotel recommended this really delightful restaurant which was around the corner from where we were staying. It was a great recommendation !  We were impressed sufficiently after having lunch there when arriving in Spain, to returning for dinner at the end of our trip...
review_full: Our hotel recommended this really delightful restaurant which was around the corner from where we were staying. It was a great recommendation ! We were impressed sufficiently after having lunch there when arriving in Spain, to returning for dinner at the end of our trip when leaving Spain. The meals are substantial and this is an authentic Spanish dining experience so its a good idea to have a healthy appetite before arriving. We tried various Spanish dishes including suckling pig and were not disappointed. There were a number of small complimentary items provided to us which were not part of the cost of the meal and this added to our enjoyment (and waistline). The menu is designed to have shared plates which was an added bonus and the cost is not excessive for the quality and quantity of what is provided to diners. Although not a large restaurant, both the dining experience and the staff have old school manners, style and generosity which are often sadly lacking in today's modern restaurants. We would return without a doubt to El Rincon de Esteban should there be a visit back to Madrid.

title_review: Come on in, the food is great!
review_preview: This is a very unassuming place on an out of the way side street.  We walked right past it the first time and were so glad we backtracked because it turned out to be one of our best meals in Madrid!The friendly waiter recommended...
review_full: This is a very unassuming place on an out of the way side street. We walked right past it the first time and were so glad we backtracked because it turned out to be one of our best meals in Madrid! The friendly waiter recommended the ham and potatoes and he was so right. It was a delight. Our other favorite was the octopus, This is a pretty basic place and the back room it really nothing to speak of but the food (and the service) are white impressive. So don't let the basic look of the place turn you off.

We shared three tapa plates,including the best octopus I have ever had, anywhere on the globe - and I mean ANYWHERE. It was so good I can't even remember the third one (but I do remember terrific croquetas).  Service was attentive and unintrusive, and we were surprised when we realized how late it was and saw we were the last guests left. Those three tapas were enough for a meal, but we tried what the English menu called Fried Milk fr dessert - unspectacular. Total bill was 110 euros,

title_review: Totally old school, in a good way
review_preview: I suspect their aren't many places like this left in Madrid......overseen by the sprightly Esteban and waiters all very smartly dressed.......starched tablecloths.......correct cutlery and crockery etc.  And walls completely covered by photos of Esteban and his customers.  Mrs Esteban in the background......of the photos and...
review_full: I suspect their aren't many places like this left in Madrid......overseen by the sprightly Esteban and waiters all very smartly dressed.......starched tablecloths.......correct cutlery and crockery etc. And walls completely covered by photos of Esteban and his customers. Mrs Esteban in the background......of the photos and the restaurant. We ordered gin and tonics, which were poured with gusto and generosity.......and no measurement whatsoever. Must have been a quadruple.........and meant we didn't finish to be able to move onto wine until the dessert. Food was traditional, but very well execued - grilled hake, roast leg of lamb, bean stew etc. All excellent in the way that comes of years of repetition........and fantastic "baked potatoes".......which were a delightful dauphinoise style rather than in a jacket. Skinny apple tart was the highlight of desserts........and then Spanish limocellos on the house all round.  A great experience and really good quality food.........only not 5 stars because the service was a tad brusque.........even overbearing at times. Esteban and his waiters should just chill a little and let their customers breathe!

title_review: Great food coupled with wonderful service
review_preview: Our hotel concierge recommended this restaurant and initially though we were a bit hesitant to enter the place as we saw a Michelin Star sign at the entrance, but we were so glad we came here! We were the only 'touristy' family with our 2...
review_full: Our hotel concierge recommended this restaurant and initially though we were a bit hesitant to enter the place as we saw a Michelin Star sign at the entrance, but we were so glad we came here! We were the only 'touristy' family with our 2 children and casual clothes, while the rest of the crowd were all business/office types in their fierce suits; my teenage son was understandably a bit worried about eating here. But the genial elderly gentleman who welcomed us (whom we thought was the Maitre d' but we found out later he was the owner!) made us comfortable with his warmth and camaraderie. The starters (grilled prawns, fried calamari) were excellent and we were pleasantly surprised to get tiny shots of complimentary lemon sorbets to clean our palate after every course. The waiter was also very friendly and chatty and explained the various bull-fight trophys and photographs adorning the walls. Their staff was very accommodating and an off-the-menu request for a pasta for my daughter was readily prepared for her! We didn't have any space for deserts but were again plesantly surprised with complimentary sweets at the end! Yes, I agree that it is really more expensive than other restaurants in Madrid, but I would say the extra services that are rendered, excellent service and ofcourse the delicious food...I would definitely recommend this place to everyone!

When we finally did decide to go in we had a great time. The restaurant is a bit snug as most of the eating places here, but since we went early we had no problems finding space for the baby stroller as well, though I expect it might be difficult if the place is a bit more crowded. The staff are extremely friendly and helpful, our waiter Antonio gave us some excellent recommendations and was extremely attentive. We had the menu which was good value for money as we got 2 tapas, 1 side dish for 2 people and a stake main plate for two people, a house wine for two is also included but they let us change it for sangria. The portions are not very big but the food tastes great. I would recommend the Partridge pate. Overall a great experience with good food, good service and great ambiance.

title_review: Simply the best Tapas we've experienced in a tucked away locale and service to match
review_preview: My wife and I were recommended this dear little cafe by a close friend and we were SO surprised!! After having eaten at the superb but very austere Sacha the night before the pureness of flavours and quality of the food were in sharp focus....
review_full: My wife and I were recommended this dear little cafe by a close friend and we were SO surprised!! After having eaten at the superb but very austere Sacha the night before the pureness of flavours and quality of the food were in sharp focus. We were amazed to find the same quality in a modern and hip cafe. We were served by Antonio and Ivan who were both superb. Antonio recommended several tapas which arrived beautifully presented in the glasses from which the Taberna takes its name (chata). The Patridge Pate, Tuna Tartare served on seaweed, super fresh guacamole, shrimp skewers and chargrilled octopus on a magnificent pimento infused mashed potato - AWESOME. But there was more to come - a super refreshing "frozen Pi√±a Colada" for a quick and light dessert. The best jug of Tinto de Verano all for less than 20‚Ç¨ a head. When you go, be guided by Antonio or Ivan, as the menu changes according to what's fresh and what the wonderful chef is making on the day. But their suggestions were PERFECT and service flawless.  Meals were served promptly and yet we never felt hurried!  We will go again!!!!

title_review: Dine in if you enjoy being ripped off!
review_preview: The bell boy at our hotel personally recomended this place & "claimed" he ate there regularly. The food was average and the price's were completely unjustified. I will say this though, Esteban & his felow staff were very charming. I now know why.. It's the...
review_full: The bell boy at our hotel personally recomended this place & "claimed" he ate there regularly. The food was average and the price's were completely unjustified. I will say this though, Esteban & his felow staff were very charming. I now know why.. It's the only way to mask the fact that you're eating at an old restaurant which has not changed with the times and is charging through the roof for average food you could make at home. Seriously guys, I'm a big Foodie and that's half the reason I enjoy travelling. So for that reason alone I'm telling you to stay away!!! There are So many awesome little Tapas bars in Madrid which leave this place for dead at less than half the price. Do yourself a favour & don't make the same mistake I did.

review_full: They are not free. Apparently an old trick, put them on the table like they are complimentary and then ask if you want them. It was expensive at 25 euros apiece for paella. But still a nice dining experience. Nice bottle of wine. Staff is very attentive. Owner chased me into the street to make sure I was "mas contento". Nice atmosphere. Got my free ball point pen, and a couple of shots of the yellow grappa were gratis, but I did catch someone giving the waiter grief about bringing us the free plate of sweets when we had not even ordered coffee. Very mixed feelings, but every Hotel in town and our tour guide all recommend it. Yes, the sardines were good. But we were forewarned. Now you are, too. 106 euros total with the tip already added in.

A great bottle of wine and we were ready for a good night sleep. It‚Äôs very accessible. We took the subway from gran via. You get off the subway stop and walk across the street. It‚Äôs in the base of an apartment building. I really recommend eating at lakasa while in madrid. not sure about the interior fake plants!

Do not miss them.  For mains we had half portions of the chicken, skate, tuna tartare and the pork loin. All were delicious, although the skate was underwhelming. At the end we shared a crime br√ªl√©e and lemon pie.  Other reviewers noted a lack of English menus and some trouble communicating with staff. We found all staff members fluent in English and English menus were provided so it appears those issues have been remedied.

review_preview: From a bar we randomly stumbled across on a Sunday evening that wasn't too packed and looked to have a few girls worth checking out, to my favourite bar in Madrid (and probably the best I've visited in 9 months). My best mate and I...
review_full: From a bar we randomly stumbled across on a Sunday evening that wasn't too packed and looked to have a few girls worth checking out, to my favourite bar in Madrid (and probably the best I've visited in 9 months). My best mate and I came in, wrestled a spot at the bar to order our first round of Gin cocktails and found a spot on the wall to lean against. The quality and size of the drinks were above my expectations (I'm a serious Gin drinker - Hendricks, Bombay and Tanqueray as the staple) and the selection of in-house distilled and infused styles were more than impressive.  Come the next Friday when our mate from London visited for the weekend we wanted to come back and share our new find. After some head scratching and detective work (saw the name of the restaurant across the road in my selfie from the Sunday) we re-found my new favourite bar. This time we widened the parameters and dabbled into some of the other liquors they distilled and I can freely confess their Rum's and Whiskey's are above par too and very drinkable. I would recommend this place to anyone who enjoys a top shelf experience, ask the bar staff for their suggestions as I did and enjoyed the ones recommended. This one gets a 10/10 from me

title_review: Probably the best tapas in Madrid
review_preview: We tried different tapas in Madrid via seven days trip. Taberna del Chato was probably the best. That¬¥s why we (family of four) were there twice. Of course the market hall is nice, but this place does all in modern, fresh way. It¬¥s unique. Try...
review_full: We tried different tapas in Madrid via seven days trip. Taberna del Chato was probably the best. That¬¥s why we (family of four) were there twice. Of course the market hall is nice, but this place does all in modern, fresh way. It¬¥s unique. Try everything, one by one! We shared all the tapas, an it was like a great food tasting whole evening. The croquetas de jam√≥n, pollo al curry, the solomillo teriyaki, the mini burgers, the octopus, the patee, desserts...you name it! The sangr√≠a is delicious and their wine list working. The restaurant is located in the downtown Madrid, near Sol, but still hidden from a tourist trap. It is small and cosy. Taberna del Chato is own by Ignacio, a friendly and always smiling guy, who takes care that you feel like home. He doesn¬¥t speak fluent English, but enough to be understand. The bartenders (both young gentleman) were pros as well in service and in English. And the bill: first evening 67 euros for four persons and in the second visit 88 euros. So it depends how hungry (and thirsty) you are. We¬¥ll be back, absolutely!

title_review: This place restored my faith in reviews.
review_preview: Tonight I did my usual research and was keen to try this restaurant based on reviews. However, having recently chosen a restaurant in Montmartre based solely on reviews and being bitterly disappointed I was a little nervous. The previous restaurant, despite its good reviews, was...
review_full: Tonight I did my usual research and was keen to try this restaurant based on reviews. However, having recently chosen a restaurant in Montmartre based solely on reviews and being bitterly disappointed I was a little nervous. The previous restaurant, despite its good reviews, was almost empty. We arrived at this restaurant at 8pm and they were only just opening the doors so a bums on seats assessment seemed unfair. With some trepidation we stayed and we're we glad that we did. We ordered five tapas each and each one seemed better than the one before. Overall the meal was totally delicious and if we were in Madrid another night we would definitely return. A fabulous meal for a very reasonable price.

review_preview: Met Esteban when I was stationed at Torrejon Air Base in the early 80's.At the time he was partner/owner of another restaurant near the Plaza Mayor. He enlightened me in the art of bullfighting and introduced me to the finer spanish cuisine. I found Esteban...
review_full: Met Esteban when I was stationed at Torrejon Air Base in the early 80's.At the time he was partner/owner of another restaurant near the Plaza Mayor. He enlightened me in the art of bullfighting and introduced me to the finer spanish cuisine. I found Esteban after searching through the internet during my last visit to Spain and was pleasantly surprised at what he had managed to achieve after opening his own restaurant. The food is excellent, although presented in it's simple and delicious form. Prime meats and seafood is the norm. Extensive wine choices, great service and attention to detail make El Rincon de Esteban well worth a visit.

If you're into views try for one of the tall tables at the front for where we were sitting we could only see other diners and grey walls. Very affordable restaurant.

review_preview: This tiny restaurant is tucked away on a long narrow alleyway near El Prado and the Palace Hotel. Nearby are other well-known and heavily booked restaurants, including some excellent seafood restaurants. But, this gem is worth the visit. The Sopa Castellana is an excellent typical...
review_full: This tiny restaurant is tucked away on a long narrow alleyway near El Prado and the Palace Hotel. Nearby are other well-known and heavily booked restaurants, including some excellent seafood restaurants. But, this gem is worth the visit. The Sopa Castellana is an excellent typical delight, with just the right amount of garlic and soaking in bread, bacon and eggs.. The Rabo de Buey Estofado is perfectly simmered and as tender an ox-stew as you will ever find. The wine pairings were perfect. The creme caramel, mouth watering. There are two different menus. Ask for the one in Spanish. I think English menu is for the less adventurous. The Spanish menus are fixed price with a wide range of fish, foul, game and meats. Go early if you want a seat and don't have reservations. Better yet, secure reservations. Service is attentive and friendly. A good place for a solo dinner.

review_full: We went there for dinner on our last night in Madrid. We have ordered around 7-8 chatos and a side dish, the quality were all outstanding! The service was good, this waiter saw us struggling to make a decision and he offered help. He speaks good english with a slight american accent. He was helpful. he made the sangria in front of us (we sat at the left side of the bar so that we were more exposed to the bar, mini food display and partial of the kitchen area). we have pretty much took his advice, we ordered the spanish cold soup, mini burger, tariyaki beef, the fried chicken was good I really enjoyed it, pate, curry chicken (came with crous crous)..the portion was just right for the two of us ( mind you we went in with empty stomach).  We were so glad we went in. As you would, we took photo of pretty much each dishes. The owner saw that and offered to take us a photo as we were trying to do a selfie hehe. He speaks ljttle english but very welcoming, most of the guests came after us greeted warmly by him, and it appears to me that they were regulars. I recalled when we order our second round, as we wanted to order more, he actually stopped us and said that should be enough for the two of us. To me this is a small restaurant that cares about your dining experience and more importantly honesty!  In the end he offered us two spainsh wine (shot?) to finish up as we couldnt fit in any dessert. He said in his slightly broken english that you have to at least try the spainsh wine ( and he didnt charge us for it). The total bill inc tax was 35 euros, and we have tiped them 4 on top for the great experience and hospitally. Highly recommended!!

review_preview: We just got back from a late lunch/early dinner at El Rincon de Esteban.  First off, we have never felt as welcome and as comfortable at a high end restaurant.  This is our 15th day in Spain, and although we have had many, many good...
review_full: We just got back from a late lunch/early dinner at El Rincon de Esteban.  First off, we have never felt as welcome and as comfortable at a high end restaurant. This is our 15th day in Spain, and although we have had many, many good meals, this was the best. The restaurant is cozy and warm, the direccion, Esteban Gonzalez Moreno, meets you at the door with a handshake and a sincere "thank you for coming".  Food was wonderful. The Castillian soup was unique and delicious. I had the baby squid and shrimp - heavenly. My wife ordered the hake cooked Balboa style - grilled with olive oil and garlic. It's now her favorite fish dish. Many extras: olive and pickle tray, sardines, an egg and potato amuse bouche, sorbet between courses, little chocolate desserts, an appertif. Go there; you will love it.

review_preview: I love this place and have been there many times over a 12 year period.  The ambience is very lively and old school.  Many photos on the walls of famous and not so famous guests.  Esteban is a wonderful  host who makes everyone feel at...
review_full: I love this place and have been there many times over a 12 year period. The ambience is very lively and old school. Many photos on the walls of famous and not so famous guests. Esteban is a wonderful host who makes everyone feel at home. The other staff follow his lead and make the evening a pleasure. They are able and willing to give advice and assistance about everything. The food has been terrific though this time, some things seemed not to be up to the normal standard. I do not know why. The salad seemed to have stayed a day longer in the kitchen than it should before being served. Still I enjoyed the meal very much. Esteban and the staff want to make sure you are happy and that everything is perfecto. It seems to have become much more popular among Americans though there are many Spanish people there as well. At least, there are no tourist buses outside. The location of the restaurant is ideal -- close ot the major art museums and other tourist stops. And close to many very good hotels.

review_preview: On our last day in Madrid we had really terrible experience with this restaurant. Given the nice interior and smiley owner, one would expect the food is also good. WRONG!!! I ordered grilled sea bass. The piece of fish that came was a  head cut...
review_full: On our last day in Madrid we had really terrible experience with this restaurant. Given the nice interior and smiley owner, one would expect the food is also good. WRONG!!! I ordered grilled sea bass. The piece of fish that came was a head cut with head bone included and not much actual fish meat. I asked to change that piece with proper middle cut fillet. They took the plate and about 15 minutes later returned exactly the same plate and same piece of fish with just bone and skin removed. After more conversation, they got it back. Another 15 minutes later the same plate was returned with half of a small fish on it. I pointed out that it is not a sea bass. They argue that it is, but got it back only to return exactly the same dish with fish turned skin up. After that I said forget it, don't bother, I don't want any fish anymore. At that point owner persuade me really hard to have their "very best" sole fish cooked. I gave up and agreed. The "perfect sole" came dry and oily, impossible to eat. This time I didn't complain just sat plate aside. However, the story was not over. This time guy with a good english came and asked what the problem. I explained everything from the beginning, and asked for a check. He insisted again they can cook fish for me, and I foolishly agreed another time. That was a mistake! Another 20 minutes, and piece of fish came on SAME plate (with same piece of already cold potato) overcooked on one side and completely raw on another. When I pointed out that fish is raw, the owner said they can cook that piece more... That was it, I insisted on having a check, and another blow - they included the charge for grilled sea bass in a bill !!! So, we have to ask to get it off the bill. And they seem to believe they are doing us a favor by removing it. Overall, they never assume any responsibility, nor apologize for ruining our dinner.

title_review: Good food, cozy place but slightly rushed service
review_preview: We went here for a dinner for three people. Having booked a table (about an hour prior to arriving), we went off to the place. When we arrived, it seemed that they did not quite have their bookings in order, as we weren't in the...
review_full: We went here for a dinner for three people. Having booked a table (about an hour prior to arriving), we went off to the place. When we arrived, it seemed that they did not quite have their bookings in order, as we weren't in the book. We did manage to get a table anyway, and got seated. We were presented with some olives and a lovely little muscle starter, while looking at the menu. We went with one of the two available menus, which included a starter, a main, a dessert, wine, coffee and a chupito. The food was very nice - everything cooked to perfection, although the fish main could have used some sauce or the similar on the side to add some flavor. The wine was very nice, and although we did not get quite as much as was stated on the menu (1/2 bottle per menu, we only got a bottle to share amongst the three of us), we did get a glass of Cava with the dessert in stead. The dessert was excellent too. We never did receive the chupito that was mentioned. The only negative thing to add for this place is, that the service seemed very rushed. We had barely taken the last bite of the starter, before the plate was taken away. We were brought a small lemon sorbet to cleanse the pallet (as we were having dishes with fish), which two of us didn't even get to start before the main dish came to the table. When pouring it seemed that the waiter did not want to spend more time than absolutely necessary at the table, which made us feel like they just wanted us out as fast as possible. When we got to the dessert things had calmed down a bit at the restaurant, and although the waiter still seemed to prefer throwing stuff around very quickly, it did seem more calm.

review_preview: After a long walking tour of Madrid, we found this beautiful restaurant filled with memorabilia and culture. The wine list was extensive and well priced. This is not a tapas joint. We had green salad with goat cheese, roast young lamb leg, and oxtail. The...
review_full: After a long walking tour of Madrid, we found this beautiful restaurant filled with memorabilia and culture. The wine list was extensive and well priced. This is not a tapas joint. We had green salad with goat cheese, roast young lamb leg, and oxtail. The oxtail was the winner with a sauce demonstrating great depth of flavor. They gave a sparkling apple flavored cava for a free dessert. The host was incredibly gracious and came outside after the meal to shake our hands and thank us for coming. We will return on the next trip to Madrid.

review_preview: We visited El Rincon de Esteban without reservation. The place was crowded, however Masha made a place for us downstairs in the cellar area, a very nice cavern type room with no more than 4 tables.The service of this lady Masha, was superb, and...
review_full: We visited El Rincon de Esteban without reservation. The place was crowded, however Masha made a place for us downstairs in the cellar area, a very nice cavern type room with no more than 4 tables. The service of this lady Masha, was superb, and every dish very tasty. This is not a gourmet restaurant, however the food quality is perfect and the portions very generous. They offer a variety of spanish food, including fish, vegetables, pork, etc. The dessert, an apple cake with ice cream was perfect.  If you are in Madrid, near the Plaza del Sol, you have to visit this place.

review_preview: It was wonderful to eat at this gem of a restaurant and see that the charming Esteban is still greeting his guests as though they are family.  Nowhere in Madrid are you welcomed with such unbridled love and hugs as when Esteban greets you at...
review_full: It was wonderful to eat at this gem of a restaurant and see that the charming Esteban is still greeting his guests as though they are family. Nowhere in Madrid are you welcomed with such unbridled love and hugs as when Esteban greets you at the entrance. The food is superb, with many choices and substantial portions---the lamb shoulder melts in your mouth---their desserts are irresistible and the after dinner drinks that are their gift to you is a charming addition. Have been going here for over a decade and the quality of the food has remained constant, as have the wait staff who are excellent. Having a meal at Esteban's is like going to a family members to eat--and you leave full, happy, and vowing to return often!!!

title_review: good food and service, although extra charge to watch out for
review_preview: The food was very good and the service was also good, but the one practice that detracts from being a top notch experience, as noted by some other reviewers here also, is that there is a charge for some items which were not ordered.  At...
review_full: The food was very good and the service was also good, but the one practice that detracts from being a top notch experience, as noted by some other reviewers here also, is that there is a charge for some items which were not ordered. At every other restaurant in the world I have eaten at they don't charge for the bread and butter on the table, but here there was a $6 charge on the bill for "pan, mantequilla y aperit" which translates as "bread, butter, and snacks and drinks." Although a review on this site had alerted me to avoid certain items even though they were on the table since they were not complimentary, I still was not able to avoid the charge for the bread, butter and small after dinner drink they served which was not ordered. It would be a better dining experience if not having to be on guard watching for the restaurant slipping in extra charges for items not ordered but served, or already on the table until explicitly refused and removed. I should have said something to the waiter at the end when getting the bill but it would be a smoother experience if not having to be so vigilant. The restaurant is smaller and older. The type of place where the owner may give a woman a kiss on the hand. They have a book in which they seem to record which hotel referred each dining guest. On a different note, regarding breakfast, in the same area, perhaps a couple blocks away, VIPS has a very good breakfast at a very reasonable price. Served quickly, good food, good price. Not the same type of dining as El Rincon de Esteban but worth noting if staying in that area.

review_preview: We happened on this restaurant by chance. Without doubt one of life's lucky chances. Service was second to none, the way all service should be. Attentive staff and a perfect host. Nothing was too much trouble. Between course sorbet, was a nice touch. The anchovy...
review_full: We happened on this restaurant by chance.  Without doubt one of life's lucky chances.  Service was second to none, the way all service should be. Attentive staff and a perfect host. Nothing was too much trouble.  Between course sorbet, was a nice touch.  The anchovy dish as a starter set the standard for the rest of the courses.  The oxtail was in a rich sauce with homemade chips. The salmon and hake dish was delicate and tasty. Both were excellent.  Dessert was homemade and heavenly.  Excellent coffee with complimentary biscuits and chocolate.  Then the owner brought us complimentary liquers, (which he topped up frequently). A perfect evening.  If you only eat out once in Madrid make this place your choice.

title_review: The devil is in the details
review_preview: With average of over 100 nights a year traveling I rarely go hotel restaurants. They are usually overpriced and the food is far from great. However, the Westin had 30% discount and we wanted to take a walk in the park nearby. The food was...
review_full: With average of over 100 nights a year traveling I rarely go hotel restaurants. They are usually overpriced and the food is far from great. However, the Westin had 30% discount and we wanted to take a walk in the park nearby. The food was decent. Nothing to write home about. What managed to upset me was a small beer for 11 Euros. If 6 months into the worst crisis for travel and tourism hotels still think they can continue with ridiculous overpricing approach they sure deserve to go out of business. I just feel sorry for hard working employees who will pay the price for incompetent and greedy management. Not likely to go back regardless of special deal etc.

review_preview: Never tried sushi before and for my first experience I wanted to go to a place that specialized in it. I'll start out by saying the food was excellent! I ordered the fried shrimp rolls with avocado and I couldn't get enough! They were delicious,...
review_full: Never tried sushi before and for my first experience I wanted to go to a place that specialized in it. I'll start out by saying the food was excellent! I ordered the fried shrimp rolls with avocado and I couldn't get enough! They were delicious, I can't wait to explore more sushi. The restaurant however was way too pretentious for me. Upon entering the completely empty restaurant the host asked us if we had a reservation to which we replied "no" and then she fussed around on her ipad for a few minutes and kept saying there was nothing available. Eventually another waiter came out and they told us we could sit and eat at the bar but as soon as we sat down they told us we could have a table-We got a table I'm not complaining-Our waiter though seemed almost annoyed that he had to help us. My friends are no strangers to sushi but having never tried it I was asking them and the waiter questions about the menu and he basically rolled his eyes and answered me in a very mono-tone voice. He never came back to the table to check on us and never spoke a word when giving us our check and cashing us out. When we left about an hour later the restaurant wasn't even half full so all that stuff about not having any space available was strange in hindsight. The food was great though! If you don't care about service and want good sushi give it a try.

review_full: I visited based on a recommendation and that La Musa was only a couple of minutes from my hotel. On a Friday night, I knew to arrive before 8 and at 7:30 it was almost full. I took a seat at the bar and noticed they have a good selection of draft beers and specialty cocktails as well smoothies.  I started with the Fried Green tomatoes. Just the right amount of crust and the fig jam and goat cheese brought it all together. Next Tapas course was the Baked Cauliflower. Excellent with the sesame yogurt sauce & Pomegranates taking it to the next level. Last course was the Calamari. A bit too much breading for me so just ok although the Wasabi dip was very good. By 8, it was packed with upbeat music playing, enhancing the lively/hip atmosphere. Great spot for having a drink and of course the Tapas are amazing all brought together with excellent service.

review_preview: We have been to La Musa with friends and family a couple times while living in Madrid. They always say that everywhere in Madrid has good tapas...well that's not really true. But the tapas at La Musa were definitely delicious! They have spanish tapas, and...
review_full: We have been to La Musa with friends and family a couple times while living in Madrid. They always say that everywhere in Madrid has good tapas...well that's not really true. But the tapas at La Musa were definitely delicious! They have spanish tapas, and "small plates" from around the world, that really cater to a bunch of different tastes. The prices are very reasonable for food and drinks, so you can try a bunch of different things in 1 meal (either to share or for yourself!) I would highly reccommend for your tapas adventures in Madrid - you won't be disappointed!

title_review: A Gem off the beaten track
review_preview: I chose this restaurant for the Friday night of our weekend in Madrid on 27/11/15 because of its good rating on TripAdvisor and its proximity to the Intercontinental Hotel. Of course being English I tried to book a table for 7.00pm and was politely told...
review_full: I chose this restaurant for the Friday night of our weekend in Madrid on 27/11/15 because of its good rating on TripAdvisor and its proximity to the Intercontinental Hotel. Of course being English I tried to book a table for 7.00pm and was politely told that the first booking was at 8:30pm. As it turned out, lunch didn't finish until 7.00pm! When we arrived the restaurant was just opening. We were greeted by the owner, Maria, who was very welcoming and spoke excellent English. We had a wonderful meal and were looked after very well by the charming hostess. The restaurant was starting to get busier when we were leaving about 9:30. We had a pleasant 15 minute walk back to the hotel. I booked the table via e-mail and was responded to promptly. I would definitely go again, but would like to see a cheese platter next time. Excellent value at 78 Euros for 2 courses each and drinks.
