title_review: Magnificent La Mama - a Hidden Gem!
review_preview: I visited this fabulous Restaurant while on a recent business trip to Madrid.  It's only been open a few months, but it's really making its mark in the locality of Madrid in which it is located. The menu is not extensive, but what it lacks...
review_full: I visited this fabulous Restaurant while on a recent business trip to Madrid. It's only been open a few months, but it's really making its mark in the locality of Madrid in which it is located. The menu is not extensive, but what it lacks in choice is very much made up for in great quality food, well chosen choices to offer, and a lovely ambience. The young owner, Maria Brufau was our host, and I understand her husband is the Chef, who incidentally, is also a magician with food. What makes it even more attractive is that their Starters can be served in half portions or as Main Courses. I had Prawn Risotto to start and it was magnificent. This was followed by one of the most succulent steaks I've had for some time. So good, just add pepper - no sauces needed! And a fabulous dessert to close. Keenly priced, with excellent quality food and wine, this Restaurant is a gem. You won't be disappointed!!

We were actually 4 stories up in an AirBnB exactly over the restaurant so we saw it often during our 5 day stay in Madrid. They have a nice menu with pizzas in Spanish style, tostadas of all types and meats, and other small items. They also have a nice wine menu, Estrella on tap, and other liquor available. Limited seating so prepare to wait or go outside the peak 1p to 3p or dinner after 8:30-9p time.

review_preview: This place was absolutely, unexpectedly fabulous. The chef/owner was amazing; he took time to talk to us before our meal and we never stopped chatting throughout. He was insanely passionate and you could feel it in the quality of the food. We tried about 8...
review_full: This place was absolutely, unexpectedly fabulous. The chef/owner was amazing; he took time to talk to us before our meal and we never stopped chatting throughout. He was insanely passionate and you could feel it in the quality of the food. We tried about 8 different dishes (maybe more) and each was better plated and tasting than the last - this cooking is the best quality that you're going to find at a local family-owned restaurant. We travelled for four weeks across Spain and France eating at the nicest places we could find and this small joint ended up being our favorite restaurant by miles. Highly recommend to anyone - can't imagine a better dining experience.

The menu is all in Spanish but the waitress was faultless and spent time explaining the whole menu to us in great English! She was really good at her job, right amount of friendly and efficient.We ordered a variety of dish...all excellent! We most enjoyed the squid, tuna and cheeks. They have the option for full or half portions. We found the half portions to be very good in size. It was minimalist and trendy inside. It was good value, we were full, with a bottle of wine for ¬£40, we couldn't never have the standard of food for this price at home.You do have to know about it to find it as it is down a smaller side street but is definitely worth finding, we couldn't recommend highly enough!

review_preview: We came here for evening meal after calling restaurants near our hotel and were lucky to reserve a table. We couldn't have made a better choice. Overall we ate six different dishes sharing them to sample the menu better and it was an excellent idea....
review_full: We came here for evening meal after calling restaurants near our hotel and were lucky to reserve a table. We couldn't have made a better choice. Overall we ate six different dishes sharing them to sample the menu better and it was an excellent idea. It was probably a bit too much for one evening, but we couldn't stop - everything was tasty - and interesting, as we learned something new with every new dish that landed on our table. I especially recommend "croquetas de jam√≥n" and "Pimientos de Piquillo rellenos de Rabo de Toro gratinado" (which is a dish made of meat from a bull's tail) as well as "Salmorejo de Almendras y Chipotle". Even our 5 yr old found something that she liked - a hamburger made without spices especially for her. We ended up with home made tarts (the toffee-caramel tart is heavenly!), coffee and a glass of pacharan, a special digestive liqueur brought by our wonderful host. Then we had to take our overfilled bodies back to the hotel freeing the table for others already waiting for a place. As I write this three days later I can also tell that everything was fresh and of good quality as we didn't have any bad side effects of our overindulgence.  Apart from great food we did get excellent service - Jose Miguel, who I think is the owner, assisted us from the start speaking both Spanish and English - he really knows what he serves, he is able to explain all the dishes, how they are made and advise what to take. He is clearly a food lover himself and was visibly pleased when we praised the dishes. The slogan in his tiny restaurant (~5 tables inside, another ~5 outside) as "Cocina con alma" - "Cooking with a soul" and the results tell that this indeed true.  If I ever happen to visit Madrid again I would definitely be back (if only I would be lucky enough to get a table).

review_full: My wife and I visited Alma Cheli on a Sunday evening in early October. It was fully booked but they squeezed us in and we were so glad they did. This is rated as one of the best restaurants in Madrid, and I can now see why. We shared several dishes including Salmorejo, meatballs, Russian Salad, and garam masala chicken. They were all first class without exception, but best of all were the homemade desserts. Combined with a traditional local Spanish setting it made for a memorable evening. Well worth a visit.

title_review: A hidden gem, and wonderful service
review_preview: Le MaM√† is a small neighbourhood restaurant off the tourist track, though nearby to the huge El Cort√© Ingles at Nuevo Ministero. We booked it purely by accident due to its good reviews on El Tenedor without regard to its non-central location.What good luck!...
review_full: Le MaM√† is a small neighbourhood restaurant off the tourist track, though nearby to the huge El Cort√© Ingles at Nuevo Ministero. We booked it purely by accident due to its good reviews on El Tenedor without regard to its non-central location. What good luck! It was by far one of the best meals I've had in Spain, and certainly the best of our most recent trip to Madrid. My sister and I were mostly bowled over by the excellent and personal service. One waitress was on duty (it is a small place) and though we didn't get her name, her attentiveness and her enthusiastic recommendations truly made our night. The white wine she recommended (an Albari√±o by Bicos) was amazing (and ridiculous value at ‚Ç¨2.30 a glass). She was super friendly and made great effort to communicate with us in her basic English and our broken Spanish. She seemed knowledgeable and passionate about the dishes and the wines. I'm not exaggerating when I say her service truly made our night. A huge departure from the surly/cold manner of some restaurant staff we'd encountered elsewhere! The food was excellent - in particular the Iberico pork cheek main. I was nervous about trying the waitress' recommendation for dessert - rice pudding with cinnamon ice cream - but it was really special. Highly recommended if you are shopping at El Cort√© Ingles. Even if not, it is well worth travelling to since it is only a few metro stops from the centre of Madrid. Our bill came to around ‚Ç¨40 for 2 courses for 2 people including a glass of wine each. Absolutely fantastic value.

The owner was ever so friendly and you could feel he loved what he was doing he talked me trough the local wines, the food he made, the different ways, ingredients etc.  The place was nicely decorated and had a rather warm and very HOMELY feel about it which was very nice. It was maybe around 10pm but it was getting busier and busier.  Food was very good ( especially the mini burgers and the ceviche) and the local madrid red wine is real cheap and absolutely fab. If you're in the area, and looking for real, no fuss and well priced tapas do pay this place a visit. You shan't be disappointed. Will return

review_preview: I have dined here before, and think the food is outstanding. I have eaten here both for breakfast, Sunday brunch, and 2 dinners. Each time, the variety and taste of the items has been stellar. The first time I ate here, I raved about the...
review_full: I have dined here before, and think the food is outstanding. I have eaten here both for breakfast, Sunday brunch, and 2 dinners. Each time, the variety and taste of the items has been stellar. The first time I ate here, I raved about the foie gras ravioli. This time I ordered a steak, which was similarly delicious. I am picky...truly picky, about food, and this is simply an exceptional restaurant in terms of its food quality. In terms of decor and ambiance, what a beautiful restaurant. The Tiffany-style glass ceiling at the center of the restaurant is absolutely gorgeous; the orchids, tulips, calla lilies, etc as table arrangements were all just gorgeous, and the piano/singer quite enjoyable. I definitely look forward to a third visit the next time my travels find me in Spain!

title_review: Best buffet in Spain - best feature of the Westin Palace Hotel, Madrid
review_preview: La Rotonda is not only a beautiful restaurant venue, centred on an elegant colonnaded stained glass dome, but it also has the best buffet breakfasts and lunches we experienced during our visit to Spain in January-February 2012. Sunday brunch was phenomenal. The quality and presentation...
review_full: La Rotonda is not only a beautiful restaurant venue, centred on an elegant colonnaded stained glass dome, but it also has the best buffet breakfasts and lunches we experienced during our visit to Spain in January-February 2012. Sunday brunch was phenomenal. The quality and presentation of tapas alone in the Rotonda's buffets puts many specialist tapas bars to shame. The Rotonda's waiters are consummate professionals who with genial courtesy maintain the highest standard of service - materialising fresh cutlery, refilling coffee, or other services as necessary, quickly and unobtrusively. We like the Rotonda so much that on our return to Madrid, when we chose to stay in an apartment, we walked back there every morning for breakfast. We looked at the buffet in the Ritz across the Paseo del Prado from the Westin Palace as a breakfast option - and immediately went back to the Westin's Rotonda. It was unfailingly a delightful place for breakfast, lunch or dinner. Not cheap at ‚Ç¨34pp for breakfast, but true value for money.

review_preview: La Rotonda is the Westin Palace Hotel's grande dame restaurant, offering Spanish cuisine, a lavish daily buffet breakfast (a separate Chinese table; thick Spanish chocolate and two kinds of churros!) and a very social Sunday Opera and Brunch event popular with locals as well as...
review_full: La Rotonda is the Westin Palace Hotel's grande dame restaurant, offering Spanish cuisine, a lavish daily buffet breakfast (a separate Chinese table; thick Spanish chocolate and two kinds of churros!) and a very social Sunday Opera and Brunch event popular with locals as well as tourists. It has even been known to host an occasional haute fashion show.  It comprises a huge, elegant dining space with inviting couches and set tables scattered along the walls and about a central circular couch under a massive stained glass dome cupola.  With extended early-to late-morning and early-afternoon-through- late-evening hours of operation, it is a most welcome respite area for exhausted guests needing a comfortable place to relax out-of-room with tasty snacks and drinks to refuel on at the odd hours of day. Just walk right in, sit down, order ... and let the strain of over-taxed sight-seeing and shopping quietly drain away.

review_preview: La Musa is located on the Calle Manuela Malasa√±a, which in itself is fun, and contains lots of fun little shops and restaurants. The place can get rather crowded, for lunch or for dinner, which tells you how popular it gets.As in other places...
review_full: La Musa is located on the Calle Manuela Malasa√±a, which in itself is fun, and contains lots of fun little shops and restaurants. The place can get rather crowded, for lunch or for dinner, which tells you how popular it gets. As in other places in Madrid, it has "specials of the day" for lunch - we tried the specials, and some of their very varied tapas. In addition to more "traditional" items the menu has California rolls, Syrian salad, Humus, tempura dishes... Japanese dumplings...  I tried the Empanadillas Japonesas (roasted Japanese dumplings), Quesadilla con Huitlacoche, Hamburguesa 4x4 (4 small hamburgers, two different sauces - my favorite was the wassabi sauce). All really good and tasty. We chose the house Rioja wine - and it was very good. The atmosphere is very comfortable, laid-back and at the same time hip. The walls have fun frames with "modern-art"-like pieces in them. It felt very comfy for lunch, and looks like a very cozy for dinner or drinks. The decor on the way to the restrooms, and the restrooms themselves are very funky as well :) While they didn't really speak English, the people working there were helpful and we communicated just fine :)  Music was playing all the time, not too loudly, so overall it was just fine. A very nice place.

We tried many of the dishes over 2 suppers and our favourites were: the Char Sui, the Fried Green tomatoes, the Bao bun., the Ceviche and the Pork Cheeks. title_review: Wonderful place for celebrating those special occasions
review_preview: We came to The Palace‚Äôs Opera Brunch to celebrate a ‚Äòround‚Äô wedding anniversary and we had a lovely restful meal after three hours on our feet at the Dal√≠ exhibition at the Reina Sofia.The Rotonda, with its spectacular stained glass dome, is an island...
review_full: We came to The Palace‚Äôs Opera Brunch to celebrate a ‚Äòround‚Äô wedding anniversary and we had a lovely restful meal after three hours on our feet at the Dal√≠ exhibition at the Reina Sofia. The Rotonda, with its spectacular stained glass dome, is an island of peace and beauty right in the artistic heart of Madrid. Its own contribution to the arts scene is the weekly Opera Brunch on Sundays. It starts at 13.30 and consists of an hour and a quarter of opera, combined with delicious food and drink. Each month the musical theme changes: July is French romantic opera with soprano and tenor, and August features opera set in Spain.... From the buffet you can create your own 6-7 course gourmet meal with small (or large!) portions of interesting creative food: stuffed artichokes, ‚Äòbombon de foie‚Äô, bresaola with goat‚Äôs cheese, cheese with pine nuts.....everything is tempting and the only limit is the size of your stomach! My wife was particularly impressed by the desserts and the chocolate fountain. The service is natural (as in not '5 star condescending‚Äô), friendly and efficient. The all-inclusive price of 77 euro per person covers everything: setting, opera, food, cava, wine, coffee, VAT..... and is good value for what you get, and I‚Äôm someone who equally writes about 9.50 euro set lunches.

review_preview: My bf and I ate at this restaurant on the very first night staying in the hotel. Our servers were impeccable and tended to all of our needs - clearing plates, topping off wine/water, offering an assortment of breads, etc. We were given a mussel...
review_full: My bf and I ate at this restaurant on the very first night staying in the hotel. Our servers were impeccable and tended to all of our needs - clearing plates, topping off wine/water, offering an assortment of breads, etc. We were given a mussel in cream sauce amuse bouche to start, compliments of the hotel, which was delicious. We then both ordered a soup - I had the broccoli soup, which was good but needed a bit more salt for my taste. My bf had the potato soup which was served from a large bowl that had enough servings for two. He said it was delicious but very filling. I had the lamb with mushrooms and it was so good. The lamb was tender and perfectly cooked and the mushrooms in this creamy sauce added such a great balance. My bf had the grilled octopus (which I should say comes as one big tentacle and not small pieces) and a salad. To top it off, I had the hazelnut tiramsu and my bf had the creme brulee, both of which were great. (I should also say I've had the raspberry sherbet and it is OUTSTANDING.) We also ate here for breakfast - once a la cart and once for the buffet. I would not recommend a la cart in the morning because the chefs were so busy making food for the buffet that our order did not come for over half an hour. Our waiter was great though, very apologetic and he went in and had them make our order right away. The buffet offers a really great assortment of not only a Western breakfast, but offers traditional breakfasts for other cultures which I thought was fantastic. Overall, I recommend going for dinner - it was my favourite meal during my time in Madrid.

review_full: We had dinner here our first night in Madrid, and breakfast here each morning. We were impressed with the service, varied menu, and delicious food. It wasnt cheap, but this is a true fine dining experience. The gazpacho was delicious (and we were served quite a generous portion), other appetisers, such as the fried goat cheese were creative and plated beautifully. The staff was friendly in elegant surroundings.  The breakfast here exceeded 5 star expectations - had everything we could possibly imagine. An assortment of fresh fruit, salads, meat, fish, yogurt, cereal, eggs, Mediterranean station with tzatziki and hummus, nan, samosas, unbelievable cheese (over a dozen types) and loose teas served in a French press.

review_preview: We ate here a couple of times while in Madrid; once at lunchtime and once in the evening.  It's in a nice square (with 3 or 4 other restaurants) a little off the beaten track but, in reality, only 5 minutes from the Plaza Mayor....
review_full: We ate here a couple of times while in Madrid; once at lunchtime and once in the evening. It's in a nice square (with 3 or 4 other restaurants) a little off the beaten track but, in reality, only 5 minutes from the Plaza Mayor. The food is excellent and a bit more varied than a lot of the other restaurants. They do something they refer to as a 'Wok' which is essentially a stir fry served with either noodles or rice and with a choice of sauces (spicy, oyster or something else). All of the different tapas we tried were excellent, even the deconstructed margarita pizza!  And they do great puddings! Try the 'Lemon Pie' - a version of lemon meringue pie! Beware though, the portions of desserts can be quite large so think about sharing if you're already quite full. At lunchtime they do an incredibly good value set lunch but the food is reasonably priced in the evening too.  The staff are generally very friendly but it does get quite busy so you need to adopt a bit of a Spanish mentality and chill! To accommodate foreigners who don't want to eat too late in the evening, they serve 'merienda' from 5.30pm till 8pm. This is a sort of enhanced range of tapas - and perfectly adequate as a meal.  We'd definitely come back if we were in Madrid again.

review_full: We really liked this area of Madrid, so we decided to walk around until we found a good restaurant and La Musa is where we ended up. We were immediately seated outside, amidst many locals, and ordered two beers along with several tapas. The food was absolutely amazing! Along with a carpaccio dish we also ordered breaded calamari and patatas bravas (fried potatoes with a spicy sauce) and another dish which is slipping my mind. The food was not only delicious, we were also full after sharing the 4 tapas. The bill came to around 30 euros, with the two beers. If you are in Madrid, this place is a must. I am so glad we stumbled upon it!!!

title_review: Believe the hype, but be prepared...
review_preview: This is mainly a follow-up on the review I wrote here some months ago about a disastrous previous visit (*link below)  I'm glad to say that I was finally conctacted by La Musa's Management and after discussing my complaint, I was invited to come for...
review_full: This is mainly a follow-up on the review I wrote here some months ago about a disastrous previous visit (*link below) I'm glad to say that I was finally conctacted by La Musa's Management and after discussing my complaint, I was invited to come for dinner on my next visit to Madrid. A very generous gesture from their part. This time it was more the kind of experience I had always had at La Musa: friendly service and absolutley stunning food. Even bearing in mind that the staff were obviously going out of their way to make sure everything was perfect on this occasion - which it was. If you have read through the rest of reviews you will have seen many enthusiastic comments. Believe the hype. I have not found a better place in this area of Madrid. Just be mindful of busy times, like Friday/Saturday night, when it's likely to be packed and you may have to wait some time for a table and then be served by a somewhat frazzled waiter. The food alone will be worth waiting (not too long though!) - try the 'tomates verdes fritos' and the 'jabal√≠ con ali-oli de miel y sobrasada' (the star of the menu), and practically everything from the 'Tapas BBQ' section. Just writing about it is mouth watering. There is really not much I can add without repeating what others have already said here. If you find yourself in Madrid and fancy trying some of the best tapas in town in one of its trendies spots, pop in La Musa. *my original review: http://www.tripadvisor.co.uk/ShowUserReviews-g187514-d1089337-r121363876-La_Musa-Madrid.html#REVIEWS

Very reasonable prices and a wonderful experience.

title_review: One great dinner; one great breakfast buffet.
review_preview: The restaurant inside the Westin Palace is lovely, with its stained glass rotunda -- obviously -- its dominant feature.  We had dinner here on Easter Sunday, figuring that most places would be closed that evening.  Then, a few days later, we had breakfast at their...
review_full: The restaurant inside the Westin Palace is lovely, with its stained glass rotunda -- obviously -- its dominant feature. We had dinner here on Easter Sunday, figuring that most places would be closed that evening. Then, a few days later, we had breakfast at their buffet. Both were very good meals, bordering on excellent. At dinner, our fish entr√©es were perfectly cooked, which in our experience, is a rare feat for a large hotel restaurant; the vegetables, fresh, crisp, and flavorful; and our appetizers delicious. The brunch buffet is HUGE -- one could only consider it small by Las Vegas standards -- and the selection of cheeses, charcuterie, cereals, yogurts, and more has just about anything you could want, and there is a "live" station where a chef will make you fresh eggs or omelets upon request. The service among the waitstaff is attentive, efficient, and friendly.

title_review: Great service and nice food in a beautiful setting

I booked a table in advance for my wife's birthday (WITHOUT making any requests or demands), and they could not have been nicer, bringing her a decorated cake for dessert.  The setting is beautiful, along one side of the domed area. We had coffee on the sofas under the dome after the meal.  The food and wine is nice; perhaps slightly more international than authentic Spanish cuisine - I had curried seafood - but very well executed. I had an extremely good glass of white albarino. Summary - very good for a special occasion.

title_review: Go here. You won't be sorry!
review_preview: I ended up at La Musa on a rainy Friday night after seeing them on Instagram (they are very active). I tried to get a reservation, but they were booked. I decided to try anyway.The restaurant is easy to access from either Metro Bilbao...
review_full: I ended up at La Musa on a rainy Friday night after seeing them on Instagram (they are very active). I tried to get a reservation, but they were booked. I decided to try anyway. The restaurant is easy to access from either Metro Bilbao (lines 1 and 4), or Metro San Bernardo (lines 2 and 4) The place was packed, and there was a long list of people hoping to get a table. Rather than wait, I watched for a spot at the bar to open up, which took only about 10 minutes. While they were very busy, the staff were very attentive, and I got a beer within a matter of minutes. Their tapas menu is extensive and I chose the salmon, which was excellent; and also the carrot cake, which was simply amazing. I was alone, which made finding a spot at the bar easier, but I highly recommend a reservation if you can get one; the website is very easy to navigate. I'll be back on my next trip to Madrid.

review_full: Found this restaurant on 'hidden tapas gems' in Madrid, or something like that. Looked up on trip advisor and reviews persuaded us to try. Got there at 8.30pm I think, Said would be a half hour wait, that wasn't a problem for us. We had a drink at the bar and then seated when ready. We went with the tasting menu as recommended by other reviewers. It didn't disappoint. Had no idea what we were eating half the time and had to use google translate to find out, but it was absolutely delicious. So pleased we went with the tasting menu as we probably wouldn't have chosen half the stuff we were given and stuck with more traditional tapas. Great meal and would definitely recommend. Great atmosphere and yes the staff are top notch, really polite and friendly.

review_preview: We went there for our wedding anniversary, recommended by the hotel. The starter of Gambas de Huelva was ok, although two of the prawns were at the limit of freshness. My wife‚Äôs starter of stuffed courgette flowers was tasteless and flabby, mainly tasting of Philadelphia...
review_full: We went there for our wedding anniversary, recommended by the hotel. The starter of Gambas de Huelva was ok, although two of the prawns were at the limit of freshness. My wife‚Äôs starter of stuffed courgette flowers was tasteless and flabby, mainly tasting of Philadelphia cheese and very little else. For my main course I had a flavourless steak with a lot of fat and nothing else on the plate. I asked for chips which were raw, then when they brought a ‚Äònew‚Äô bowl, they were hard and burnt. The other main was a stuffed partridge which was dry and inedible with an over-reduced sweet/salty sauce.  The front of house staff were ok, but the chef came into the restaurant on a number of occasions; smelling strongly of cigarettes and raising his voice to the staff, so that the atmosphere was quite unpleasant. And to cap it all, the chef came and asked sarcastically if the partridge was dry, was that why we didn‚Äôt eat it! I said yes but didn‚Äôt want to talk further with him, so after paying we left. The manager did come through to find us in the hotel a little later to apologise and to offer a free meal on the next night, but I‚Äôm afraid we turned that down, we didn‚Äôt want try it again!

He also tricked us a couple of times with the order: he tried to include one Starter too many, then included a full portion instead of the half we had ordered, and particularly irritating, he included the much more expensive version of one dish (with white truffle) without clarifying there were two versions - even when we had pointed to the cheaper one. I AM NOT GOING BACK. And it is a shame since the food was good - but not excellent as it used to be (the squid was too salty and was served cold).

Our meal was paired with a dry and crisp Verdejo that  was a delightful accompaniment. For a sweet ending, we shared a silky flan and individual presses of chamomile tea; a perfect ending to a divine dining experience.

title_review: Excellent restaurant not far from Plaza de Santa Ana
review_preview: My husband and I went La Entretenida 3 or 4 times on our fall trip to Madrid.  It was quite near and recommended by our 5 star hotel a few blocks away.  Opens at noon and remains open very late.  Great menu from wonderful Spinach...
review_full: My husband and I went La Entretenida 3 or 4 times on our fall trip to Madrid. It was quite near and recommended by our 5 star hotel a few blocks away. Opens at noon and remains open very late. Great menu from wonderful Spinach salad, burgers, to all kinds of Spanish food. They always presented us with a little amuse bouche, and we had very good wine and/or white sangria most meals. Friendly staff, pleasant environment, and never seemed loud or noisy, even when filled. Forget the tapas, and have a lovely meal here instead!

review_preview: There is no doubt that the kitchen is above average especially in the Salamanca neighborhood which is a culinary wasteland peppered with fun bar/restaurants for well heeled tourists.  What's disappointing is that the service is well below the very high prices  our waiter suggested they...
review_full: There is no doubt that the kitchen is above average especially in the Salamanca neighborhood which is a culinary wasteland peppered with fun bar/restaurants for well heeled tourists. What's disappointing is that the service is well below the very high prices our waiter suggested they had run out of whole wheat bread before showing up with two slices on a bread plate that he had taken from the upstairs dining room as if he were doing us a favor! The rices are absurd for Madrid. A class of Laurent Perrier non vintage champagne at ‚Ç¨12 prices the bottle at ‚Ç¨120!! An after dinner local liqueur which is usually on the house in Spain goes for ‚Ç¨8 a shot (while a 1l bottle of that liqueur retails for ‚Ç¨12). A tiny lobster was ‚Ç¨90 etc... For ‚Ç¨280 for dinner for 2 with three glasses of wine you can do much better in Madrid, or almost anywhere else. In addition to these price gouging there are the questions of comfort and health. This restaurant is for people who like to dine at very high temperatures in winter and summer and who don't mind or enjoy the cigars that were been smoked (illegally) in the second floor dining room to seep in during desert. Will not go back.
